content.text:
The lowest federal courts in the American judicial system are the district courts. There are 94 federal district courtsâ€”at least one in every state and as many as four in some states. These district courts are the chief trial courts of the federal system, meaning that almost all criminal and civil cases arising under federal law are argued first in the district courts.

Cases that are appealed from district courts go to federal courts of appeals, which are the second level of the federal court system. The United States has 13 courts of appeals. Eleven of these have jurisdiction over a "circuit" comprising from three to nine states. The other two appeals courts hear cases arising in the District of Columbia and cases involving patents and trade (U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit).

hotspots.hotspot:
Political appointment

Governors select judges in these states, except for Virginia, South Carolina, and Connecticut where the legislature appoints the judges.

Partisan/nonpartisan election

Judges in these states are elected by votes in partisan or nonpartisan elections. The judges can be state, county, or city judges.

Merit plan

These states use a "merit system," or the Missouri Plan. The plan permits the governor to select judges from a list of nominees recommended by a special commission. The judge must be approved in a public vote after serving for a designated period of time.

hotspots.hotspot: This is the Northeast. Many of the nation's largest cities are located in this region. One of the region's characteristics is diversity — many cultures, ethnic groups, and religions are found here. Political scientists associate these demographic differences and the heavily urban population with the fact that citizens have voted overwhelmingly Democratic in past presidential elections.

This is the southern region. These states, along with states in the Southwest, have been referred to as the "Sunbelt." This region is characterized by large rural areas. Southern voters tend to be religious and conservative. For many years, the term "solid South" was used to describe this area. Because of its conservative leanings, the region usually supports the Republican Party.

States in this region are often referred to as "swing states" because they are not heavily dominated by one of the two major parties. The region is also known by the nickname the "rust belt" due to its loss of manufacturing jobs. Conservative populations shifting from the rural areas to the cities have caused the region to move more toward the center of the political spectrum. Swing states are extremely important to presidential candidates because they may "swing" from one party to the other in an election.

This region is called the Midwest, or the Great Plains states. It has been loyally Republican for many years, and was the center of the Populist and Progressive movements in the late 1800s. Large farms and rugged individualism create a strong foundation for conservative ideologies.

This region is known as the Mountain West. It is not as diverse as other regions in the nation. Its population is conservative and individualistic. In some places, voters have indicated a strong mistrust of government. It can be said that this region is the most libertarian of all the regions in the nation. Libertarians believe in less government involvement in citizens' lives.

The Southwest is one of the nation's fastest growing areas. The states here are an extension of the Sunbelt. The region's growing population may be due to retiring baby boomers (Americans born right after World War II) from the northeast and Midwest. Because of the region's proximity to Mexico, immigration is a growing state and national issue here.

This region is known as the Pacific West. It covers the entire length of the country, from Canada to Mexico. This region is very diverse. A strong concern for the environment, strong support for freedom of ideas, and a diverse population cause this region to be a stronghold of Democrats.

This is the newest region in the nation. Both Alaska and Hawaii were added as states in the 1950s. Alaska is not as diverse as other parts of the nation. Politically, Alaska is conservative and is a stronghold for the Republican Party. Hawaii is more diverse and has voted consistently for Democratic presidential candidates.
